name: Network Cryptography
description: Sector template for cryptographic patents including encryption algorithms, key exchange protocols, digital signatures, hash functions, and cryptographic protocol implementations.
contextDescription: Network cryptography patents cover fundamental cryptographic primitives and protocols used to secure communications. Technologies include symmetric/asymmetric encryption, key exchange (DH, ECDH), digital signatures, hash functions, and cryptographic protocol design (TLS, SSH).
scoringGuidance: Post-quantum cryptographic algorithms (lattice-based, hash-based signatures) are extremely high value.
Novel cryptographic primitives that improve security/performance trade-offs score highly.
Patents on side-channel resistant implementations have significant hardware relevance.
Standardization potential (NIST, IETF) dramatically increases licensing opportunity.

questions.question: What type of cryptographic primitive does this patent cover? Score 1-3 for application of existing crypto, 4-6 for optimization/implementation of standard crypto, 7-10 for novel cryptographic algorithm or protocol.
questions.reasoningPrompt: Identify the cryptographic primitive: encryption, signature, hash, key exchange, or novel.

questions.question: What is the cryptographic security strength? Score 1-3 for weak/outdated (DES, MD5), 4-6 for current standards (AES-128, SHA-256), 7-10 for future-proof (AES-256, post-quantum).
questions.reasoningPrompt: Assess security strength in bits and resistance to known attacks.

questions.question: Does this patent address implementation security? Score 1-3 if not addressed, 4-6 for basic secure coding, 7-10 for side-channel resistance (timing, power, fault attacks).
questions.reasoningPrompt: Describe implementation security: side-channel resistance, constant-time operations.

questions.question: How efficient is the cryptographic operation? Score 1-3 for computationally expensive, 4-6 for standard performance, 7-10 for highly optimized or hardware-accelerated.
questions.reasoningPrompt: Assess computational efficiency and hardware acceleration potential.

questions.question: Does this patent have standardization potential? Score 1-3 if proprietary only, 4-6 for compatible with standards, 7-10 for standards-essential or NIST/IETF submission candidate.
questions.reasoningPrompt: Identify standardization relevance: NIST, IETF, IEEE, ISO potential.
